posts.cooked:
Hello, there are bunch of vendor libraries for simulation and logging frameworks out there used mainly by teams. I have a general inquiry about the process of simulation and logging. Is native wplib DataLogManager efficient for data visualization? Or should I use other frameworks like DogLog or AdvantageKit. I have also two other questions:

How can I simulate my code without any hardware wired and log the data of my robot position with both encoders and vision and afterwards visualize it with advantagescope.

How can I log my code while running on the robot and then analayze the data from a log viewer. Are these two built differently or are they alike? I would be grateful if you clarified me.

posts.name: Andrew Todd
posts.cooked:
I‚Äôm pretty new to simulation too. This year we‚Äôre trying out Advantage Kit.

So far our of the box, if you simulate your robot code, you can pick up the data with advantage scope no problem. You can even drive it around on this year‚Äôs field. Just a couple button clicks. We already discovered a couple small issues in the code using just that. I want to try getting the full maple-sim example running at some point.

posts.name: meer
posts.cooked:
I recommend using the default logging with epilogue built into WPILib, along with the Simulation classes built into WPILib.

Don‚Äôt let others scare you into thinking you need something like AdvantageKit. I was once in your shoes wondering what to pick and where to go,

if you want to be able to rerun your code with logs and test new code without the robot, then do advantage kit. if you don‚Äôt, use any other logging firmware

imo advantage kit has a bad habit of being connected to simulation stuff, they are separate and one helps the other but it is not needed (fun fact: the logo of advantage kit is a time rewind to show u can rerun inputs to test new code without running it on the bot).

while it may seem useful to rerun this new code on the bot, it is only really useful in specific situations where you have specific things programmed in specific ways.

if your IO layers are written incorrectly you wont get the results you intended from the new code on the bot.

I personally recommend using simple logging firmwares like epilogue and DogLog (581‚Äôs super simple logging), because they are extremely simple (like 1 line to log a whole subsystem) but keeping the IO structure from AdvantageKit to keep you simulation and real robot code organized.

not too many teams do this structure but it is effectively the same thing as advantage kit without the worries from the issues with log replay

(note, log replay is not the same as review. you can review logs in advantage scope with any logging firmware, you cannot replay these logs like advantage kit does unless you use advantage kit. also another note, I don‚Äôt have anything against advantage kit, its honestly a super useful tool for certain high level teams, credit to Jonah Bonner for writing and developing it. but for teams which don‚Äôt have the best programming or best practices, it adds a lot of unneccesary complexity.)

posts.name: Dan Katzuv
posts.cooked: I think in this time of the season, use Epilogue. We use AdvantageKit but it requires quite a bit of learning, so I recommend to try it in the off-season, not now.
Thank you, I‚Äôll take the simpler logging framework while keeping the structure clean and tidy

posts.name: Val
posts.cooked:
Also a robot simulation can range in complexity it doesn‚Äôt have to be at the motor level.

Simulation can be as simple as logging the trapezoid motion profile‚Äôs current state and tying it to a mechanism 2d. then boom! a mechanism is ‚Äúsimulated‚Äù and can show you how the mechanism is going to look (because a well tuned pid controller will follow the motion profile) Advantage scope is an amazing tool for rendering logs and viewing simulations! especially when using tools that automatically log data on network tables (ie pathplanner, yagsl, and a bunch of other ones).
